data.text: Contents
Practitioner request to introduce an interventional procedure to the Trust .................... 7

References ................................................................................................................. 10  Equality impact assessment ....................................................................................... 11 Appendix 1: Introducing new or modified interventional procedures - flowchart ................ 12 Appendix 2: Application form to introduce new interventional procedures ......................... 12 Appendix 3: New interventional procedure - clinician validation form ................................ 16 Appendix 4: Preliminary Equality Analysis ......................................................................... 17
Policy for the Introduction of New Interventional Procedures/ MSEPO-20245 /1.2
Page  of
Introduction

Medical advances and innovation are essential and should be encouraged, but patient safety is paramount. Trusts are required to have a system in place to manage innovation that is in line with national requirements laid down by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE, 2016).
The aim of this policy is to reduce the risks to patients where the introduction of procedures/equipment new to the Trust or new to the individual practitioner is planned.

The policy explains what staff need to do prior to performing an interventional procedure that they have not used before to ensure that the safety of patients is protected and to support practitioners and the Trust in managing clinical innovation responsibly.
Scope

This policy outlines the process to be followed by all staff when considering introducing a new technology or procedure. This policy provides guidance to support clinicians and managers in managing the clinical risks associated with both procurement of new clinical equipment and the introduction of new and modified clinical procedures.

This policy applies to all healthcare professionals introducing clinical procedures, surgical/medical techniques or equipment new to the Trust, planning a major transformation of existing, accepted procedures and practice or undertaking procedures that are established within the Trust but are new to the individual.
This policy does not apply to:
Clinicians in training

Research techniques – If the profession considers a procedure or treatment is sufficiently novel as to require special training and assessment before being introduced into clinical practice, then its use should be limited to a number of specified centres for clinical trials - refer to local Research & Development Management Policies or contact the Research Department
Minor incremental changes or developments
New drug treatments, these are considered by the South East Essex Medicines Management Committee
When a new procedure is for use within a completely new specialty / service as defined by the Medical Director or Chief Medical Officer. This does not exempt the procedure from NICE IPG requirements.
Definitions

table_items.text: A procedure used for diagnosis or for treatment, which involves one of the following: making a cut or a hole to gain access to the inside of a patient's body - for example, when carrying out an operation or inserting a tube into a blood vessel gaining access to a body cavity (such as the digestive system, lungs, womb or bladder) without cutting into the body - for example, examining or carrying out treatment on the inside of the stomach using an instrument inserted via the mouth using electromagnetic radiation (which includes X-rays, lasers, gamma-rays and ultraviolet light) - for example, using a laser to treat eye problems.

An interventional procedure should be considered new if a clinician, no longer in a training post, is using it for the first time in their NHS clinical practice. New also refers to techniques or procedures which are not normally performed on a specific hospital site even if the clinician already undertakes this procedure at another MSE site.

A modification is defined as one that could have a staff or clinical team training requirement and/or impacts on resource cost and meets any of the following criteria: A treatment modality and equipment already in use in the Trust but to be used for a different purpose by a practitioner as an extension to their practice. A technique where new instrumentation has to be used including a new purchase or loan equipment either requiring or not requiring consumables. Whether changes represent minor or major transformation of existing, accepted methods and practice will be a clinical decision. This will normally be apparent but inevitably there will be grey areas. In the first instance the Clinical Directorate Team will discuss the new surgical or medical technique before being approved.
It is defined as the minimum level of skill, knowledge and/or expertise derived through training and experience recognised by peers as sufficient to train and mentor others in that skill.
A consultant, doctor, nurse, therapist or specialist who by training, experience and position is contracted to undertake interventional procedures within the Trust.
A supervisor specifically appointed to supervise and deem competence for practitioners training to carry out a new interventional procedure.

Technology appraisals are recommendations on the use of new and existing medicines and treatments within the NHS in England and Wales. This guidance is of relevance to this policy when associated with medical devices, diagnostic techniques and surgical procedures.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities

MSE Health Technology Appraisal Group (Virtual) is responsible for providing assurance to the MSE Patient Safety and Quality Group that the clinical risks associated with both procurement of new clinical equipment and the introduction of new and modified health technologies are identified and addressed in a consistent manner.

MSE NICE Implementation Group has the responsibility of reviewing compliance to published NICE IPGs and for ensuring that procedures identified by NICE as ‘not for use within the NHS' are not carried out within the Trusts.

Divisional / Directorate Clinical Governance Groups are responsible for providing initial agreement for the introduction of a new interventional procedure and approving the practitioner(s) as competent to perform the procedure. The Groups are also responsible for ensuring that clinical audits are completed for new interventional procedures as indicated on the interventional procedure application form.
Chief Medical Officer is responsible for ensuring a policy is in place for the introduction of new technologies and interventional procedures.

Site Medical Director (s) are responsible for ensuring implementation of this policy and for ensuring that NICE is notified when an application has been made to perform a new interventional procedure not listed on the NICE website (www.nice.org.uk/ip).
The Medical Director will ensure any requests from Clinical Directors are clarified on whether a procedure has been modified.

4.6.1  They or their delegated deputy are responsible for reviewing applications to carry out a new or modified interventional procedure and for providing clinical governance approval for the use of these procedures. They will also review the use of a new or modified interventional procedure in a clinical emergency and consider its approval for future use.

Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring all healthcare professionals are aware of this policy and for ensuring any new or modified procedure receives approval prior to introduction (except where used in an emergency).

4.7.1 Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that new interventional procedure applications are agreed within the Division / Directorate before being presented to the relevant group / individual for review and approval. Clinical Directors are also responsible for ensuring a business case is submitted for approval where additional resources are required.
4.7.2 Clinical Directors will seek advice from the Medical Director on modifications should clarity be required.

4.7.3 Clinical Directors are also responsible for ensuring that the relevant Risk Register is updated if there are significant risks identified or a new interventional procedure for which NICE has issued technology appraisal guidance is not going to be implemented.
Practitioners

4.8.1 When wishing to undertake a new or modified interventional procedure, practitioners are responsible for bringing it to the attention of their Clinical Director and seeking clinical approval for its use from their Divisional Clinical Governance Group and relevant Trust Medical Director (or deputy) by completing the application form in Appendix
4.8.2 Practitioners using a new or modified interventional procedure in a clinical emergency should notify the Medical Director within 72 hours.
4.8.3 Practitioners are also responsible for notifying NICE when making an application to perform a new interventional procedure that is not listed on the NICE website (www.nice.org.uk/ip).

Site Clinical Effectiveness Teams are required to disseminate information about new NICE publications within the Trust, withdrawal or change to NICE guidance, to maintain the register of interest for IPGs and provide administrative support to the approval process.
Practitioner request to introduce an interventional procedure to the
Trust
Application Process - refer to Appendix 1 for decision flowchart
Divisional agreement

5.2.1 Practitioners wishing to introduce a new or modified interventional procedure into the Trust must in the first instance bring this to the attention of their Clinical Director. If clarification is required on whether to define a procedure as modified, the Clinical Director will seek advice from the Medical Director or their deputy.

5.2.2 Prior to introducing the procedure, practitioners must apply to the Divisional/Directorate Clinical Governance Group for agreement before seeking clinical governance approval. Clinical approval of a procedure does not guarantee implementation if a business case is rejected.
Complete application form (Appendix 2)
5.3.1 Application forms are available on the Trust intranet or can be obtained from the Risk and Compliance Team (mse.riskandcompliance@nhs.net)
5.3.2 Ensure the completed proposal is reviewed at the Directorate/ Divisional Clinical Governance Meeting and approved by the Clinical Director before submission for approval.
5.3.3 Completed application forms should be sent for approval to manori.jayasekera1@nhs.net
Procedures used in an emergency

5.4.1 It is recognised that in rare circumstances, where no other treatment options exist, there may be a need to use a new procedure in a clinical emergency so as not to place a patient at serious risk. If a practitioner has performed a new interventional procedure in such circumstances, they must inform the Medical Director within 72 hours.
5.4.2 The practitioner must ensure that they complete the application form (appendix 2) and return this to the appropriate individual as described above for consideration of approval for future use.
Procedures used as demonstrations

5.5.1  In the event an external source or company provides training or a demonstration of a new or modified interventional procedure with direct involvement of patients, approval should be sought as in  above prior to it being allowed to be performed at the hospital site.
Approval Process
5.6.1  The Medical Director or their deputy will notify the practitioner of the outcome of the application.
Approval granted
5.7.1 The responsibility for implementation lies with the Directorate / Division. The practitioner is responsible for ensuring local clinical guidelines are written or updated.

5.7.2 The Divisional Clinical Governance Group will add the interventional procedure to the clinical audit programme as detailed on the application form and present the outcomes at the relevant site forum.
Approval not granted

5.8.1 In the case where approval for the introduction of the interventional procedure has not been granted, the practitioner will be provided with details of any additional requirements needed for reconsideration of a future application (i.e. awaiting publication of NICE IPG, further evidence of training, safety issues, funding etc.).
5.8.2 In the event that the proposal is rejected, reasons for the decision will be provided.
5.8.3 The Medical Director or deputy will reconsider applications in light of new evidence and provisions.
Equipment

5.9.1 The Clinician should ensure that where a new procedure involves use of new equipment the Head of Biomedical Engineering (BME) is informed and the equipment included on the Directorate/Trust Equipment Register and staff training records maintained accordingly.
5.9.2 New equipment for this purpose should be acceptance tested by BME before being used. Refer to the Safe Use of Medical Devices Policy.
5.9.3 All loan / lease and rental medical equipment must conform with all relevant standards pertaining to the type of medical equipment, the location and function for which it is to be used.

Loan equipment / Lease equipment will be subjected to acceptance testing and other medical equipment management procedures accordingly, including indemnity number, equipment competency and maintenance support and included on the Equipment Management System (F2);
Accompanied by appropriate Information and training instructions.
Training requirements

Practitioners wishing to undertake a new or modified interventional procedure must be able to demonstrate that they have been trained to do so to a competent level using the Clinician Validation Form (Appendix 3). They will need to have been mentored during their training and the proctor must be with the Practitioner when they perform the first procedure. Evidence of training should be kept on file as part of the clinicians training record.

All newly appointed consultants will be expected to have either a Certificate of Completion of Specialist Training (CCST) for the speciality or equivalent. Before undertaking any specialist procedure they would need to provide evidence of appropriate training. The same scrutiny applies to locum consultants, staff, associate specialist and specialty (SAS) doctors and specialist registrars before they can perform a specialist procedure without supervision.
Practitioners found to be incapable or physically unable to be deemed competent after a suitable period of training should be advised not to undertake the procedure.

Practitioners must also ensure that other staff affected by the introduction of the new or modified interventional procedure have received appropriate training and been fully informed about the changes.

data.url: MSEPO-20245 MSE New technologies and interventional procedures policy 1.2.003.png

data.text: Monitoring and audit
If an adverse event occurs in association with a new interventional procedure, this should be reported in accordance with the Trust Incident Reporting Policy.

Practitioners will be required to undertake a clinical audit of the new interventional procedure as detailed and agreed on the application form and present the outcomes within the specified timeframe. The Directorate/Divisional Clinical Governance Group will ensure that clinical audits for new interventional procedures are completed and monitored and assurance will be provided to the relevant trust Risk and Compliance Group

data.text: Approval and implementation
This document will be approved by the Medical Directors across all 3 sites and will be agreed by the MSE NICE Implementation Group.
Staff will be informed when the document is issued and loaded onto the Staff intranets via the communication process on each site.
References
Interventional procedures programme manual 2016 NICE www.nice.org.uk/process/pmg18
NICE interventional procedures guidance www.nice.org.uk/About/what-we- do/ourprorgammes/NICE-guidance/NICE-interventional-procedures-guidance
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a service
that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 4)

Appendix 3: New interventional procedure - clinician  validation form

data.url: MSEPO-20245 MSE New technologies and interventional procedures policy 1.2.005.png

data.text: New Interventional Procedure - Clinician Validation Form
This form is to be completed by practitioners prior to independently performing a procedure which is either new to them or to the Hospital site / Trust.

All new procedures must be compliant with recommendations published by NICE (if relevant) and have been approved by the Directorate / Divisional Clinical Governance Group, Clinical Director and relevant Medical Director (or deputy).
A practitioner who has been or is being trained to perform a new procedure must have this form completed.
